stories.text:
throwaway account for obvious reasons; here's the background, though:

- startup founded in early 2010's, and recently closed Series X fundraising. The company is now profitable and has a decent war chest - employees hold options/common stock and they're now worth $$$$ - with the recent MEGA fundraising, employees have the opportunity to purchase preferred stock, same price as the most recent fundraising - if IPO'd, there's a 9 month cliff from selling.

Is this a common practice? What are the benefits of purchasing preferred stocks, given I have commons? What else to look for? And what would you do as an employee in this instance?
stories.title: Ask HN: Employer offering preferred stocks, is this normal?
Cuttlefish remember details of their last meal, study finds

stories.text: I've just realized that I'm spending a lot of time doing the same tasks over and over again in a non-procedural manner, not really gathering a large collection of insights because just doing stuff ephemerally in notebooks is fast and forgettable. What are the best tools and approaches out there that have made you significantly more productive?
stories.title: Ask HN: Best tools/practices for machine learning productivity?
Can the human body handle rotating artificial gravity?
